title: 108_s2980
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction Act of 2004". Congress finds that the possession of weapons of mass destruction by hostile states or terrorist groups is the greatest threat to national security. It is a top priority to protect the US and its allies from such attacks. The US policy is to ensure compliance with the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, Chemical Weapons Convention, Biological Weapons Convention, IAEA safeguards system, and control lists of MTCR, AG are key international agreements and mechanisms for preventing the spread of weapons of mass destruction. The United States has benefited from key international agreements like the Nunn-Lugar Act and its successors in enhancing national security interests. The Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program has been effective as of October 2004. As of October 2004, the Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program has deactivated thousands of nuclear warheads, destroyed missiles and launchers, eliminated bombers, submarines, and nuclear test tunnels. President George W. Bush called for its expansion on February 11, 2004. President George W. Bush called for the expansion of the Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program in 2004, highlighting the efforts to prevent weapons and dangerous materials from falling into the wrong hands. The program, established in 1991 by Congress, aims to provide employment for former Soviet weapons scientists, dismantle and secure weapons and materials from the Soviet WMD arsenal. More work is needed to continue these efforts. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The sense of Congress is that the US must utilize all capabilities to prevent catastrophic terrorism using weapons of mass destruction. This includes pursuing a strategy involving multilateral agreements, export controls, missile defense, and holding nations accountable for dangerous weapons. The United States must hold nations accountable for violations of international nonproliferation treaties and provide assistance to uphold these standards. The President should have authority to use Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction funds to reduce the threat of weapons of mass destruction. SEC. 4. Cooperative Threat Reduction programs are defined as specified in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1997. Repeal of restrictions on Soviet Nuclear Threat Reduction Act of 1991, Cooperative Threat Reduction Act of 1993, and Russian Chemical Weapons Destruction Facilities. Inapplicability of other restrictions. SEC. 6. INAPPLICABILITY OF OTHER RESTRICTIONS. Section 502 of the Freedom for Russia and Emerging Eurasian Democracies and Open Markets Support Act of 1992 shall not apply to any Cooperative Threat Reduction program. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION FROM LIMITATIONS. Cooperative Threat Reduction programs may be carried out notwithstanding any other provision of law, subject to congressional notification and reporting requirements. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF AUTHORITY TO USE COOPERATIVE THREAT REDUCTION PROGRAM FUNDS OUTSIDE THE FORMER SOVIET UNION. Section 1308 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 is amended to replace "President" with "Secretary of Defense", modify project criteria to address proliferation threats and nonproliferation goals, and shorten completion time. Subsections (c) and (d) are removed. Section 1308 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 is amended to replace "President" with "Secretary of Defense", modify project criteria to address proliferation threats and nonproliferation goals, and shorten completion time. Subsections (c) and (d) are removed, and subsection (e) is redesignated as subsection (c). SEC. 9. SPECIAL REPORTS ON ADHERENCE TO ARMS CONTROL AGREEMENTS AND NONPROLIFERATION COMMITMENTS. The Secretary of State must annually report to specific Senate and House committees on countries participating in Cooperative Threat Reduction programs. The report must detail each country's commitments to investing in infrastructure for securing and destroying weapons of mass destruction, limiting military modernization, and refraining from using materials from deactivated nuclear weapons in new programs. The Secretary of State must report annually on countries in Cooperative Threat Reduction programs, detailing commitments to secure and destroy weapons of mass destruction, limit military modernization, and prevent the use of deactivated nuclear weapon components in new programs. Compliance with arms control agreements, export controls, and verification by the US and international community are also required. Reports may be submitted with those required under the Arms Control and Disarmament Act.
